bestBHT.bht: Our Lord clearly refers to the feeding of the five thousand and the four thousand as distinct miracles. The differences in location, circumstances, timing, fasting period, and the number of people fed make it evident that these were separate events. Mark emphasizes this distinction by omitting the detail about women and children. The baskets mentioned in this account are further clarified in Matthew 14:20.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Had not our Lord distinctly referred, in this very chapter and in two successive sentences, to the feeding of the five thousand and of the four thousand as two distinct miracles, many critics would have insisted that they were but two different representations of one and the same miracle.
In view of these things, who could have believed that these were one and the same miracle, even if the Lord Himself had not expressly distinguished them?

The localities, though both on the eastern side of the lake, were different; the time was different; the preceding and following circumstances were different; the period during which the people continued fasting was different—in the one case not even one entire day, in the other three days; the number fed was different—five thousand in the one case, in the other four thousand.
Marvin Vincent: Four thousand. Matthew (xv. 38) here adds a detail which we should rather expect in Mark : beside women and children.
Philip Schaff: Mark 8:9. Mark again omits ‘besides women and children.’
John Gill: And he sent them away; some that came dumb, with their speech, and deaf, with their hearing; others that were maimed, with perfect healing of their wounds, and with their limbs sound and whole; others that came lame, he dismissed leaping; and others that were blind, with their sight restored to them, and all of them full.
And they that had eaten were about four thousand.
That is, men, besides women and children, as Matthew observes.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Mark 8:9, our Lord distinctly refers to the feeding of the five thousand and the feeding of the four thousand as two distinct miracles. The localities, circumstances, time, and number of people fed were all different between the two incidents. Mark emphasizes the distinction even further by omitting the detail of besides women and children. It is clear that these were separate acts of provision and not one and the same miracle. The baskets mentioned in this verse are further explained in Matthew 14:20.

Our Lord himself distinguishes the feeding of the five thousand and the feeding of the four thousand as two separate miracles. The differences in location, timing, circumstances, fasting period, and the number of people fed reinforce this distinction. Mark's omission of the detail regarding women and children in this account further emphasizes the individuality of each miracle. The baskets mentioned in this account are explained in Matthew 14:20.

Our Lord clearly refers to the feeding of the five thousand and the four thousand as distinct miracles. The differences in location, circumstances, timing, fasting period, and the number of people fed make it evident that these were separate events. Mark emphasizes this distinction by omitting the detail about women and children. The baskets mentioned in this account are further clarified in Matthew 14:20.

In this particular passage, it is evident that the feeding of the five thousand and the feeding of the four thousand were two distinct miracles. Our Lord makes it clear that these events were different, as the locations, circumstances, timing, fasting periods, and the number of people fed all varied. Mark further emphasizes the individuality of these miracles by omitting the mention of women and children. The baskets mentioned in this account are more deeply explained in Matthew 14:20.

Our Lord distinctly refers to the feeding of the five thousand and the four thousand as separate miracles in this account. The various differences in location, circumstances, timing, fasting period, and number of people fed make it clear that these were distinct events. Mark further emphasizes this by omitting the detail regarding women and children. The mention of baskets in this account can be further explored in Matthew 14:20.
